name: Kabuki Syndrome
description: Kabuki syndrome is a rare, multisystem disorder characterized by distinctive facial features (arched eyebrows, long palpebral fissures with eversion of the lateral portion of the lower eyelids, prominent ears), skeletal abnormalities, intellectual disability, and postnatal growth deficiency. Other common features include congenital heart defects, kidney abnormalities, and immune deficiencies.
symptoms: Distinctive facial features (arched eyebrows, long palpebral fissures, everted lower eyelids)
prognosis: The prognosis varies depending on the severity of the symptoms and associated complications. Many individuals with Kabuki syndrome can live relatively normal lives with appropriate medical management and support.
lifeExpectancy: Life expectancy is generally normal, although individuals with severe complications may have a reduced lifespan.

treatmentOptions.name: Surgical correction of congenital heart defects

eli5Summary: Kabuki syndrome is a rare condition that makes kids look a little different, learn at a slower pace, and sometimes have problems with their heart, kidneys, or immune system. Doctors can help them with these problems so they can live happy lives.
clinicalSummary: Kabuki syndrome is a rare congenital disorder characterized by distinctive facial features, intellectual disability, postnatal growth deficiency, and various systemic anomalies. It is primarily caused by mutations in the KMT2D (lysine methyltransferase 2D) gene on chromosome 12q13.12 or the KDM6A (lysine demethylase 6A) gene on chromosome Xp11.3. These genes are involved in histone methylation, a crucial epigenetic mechanism regulating gene expression during development. Clinical manifestations are highly variable, even within families, and can include cardiac, renal, skeletal, and immunological abnormalities. Diagnosis is typically based on clinical findings and confirmed by genetic testing. Management is multidisciplinary, focusing on addressing specific symptoms and complications.
historicalBackground: Kabuki syndrome was first described independently by two Japanese researchers, Dr. Yoshikazu Niikawa and Dr. Norio Kuroki, in 1981. The name "Kabuki" refers to the traditional Japanese theater, as the facial features of affected individuals were thought to resemble the makeup of Kabuki actors.

recentBreakthroughs.title: Novel therapeutic targets identified for Kabuki syndrome
recentBreakthroughs.description: Research has identified potential therapeutic targets for Kabuki syndrome by investigating the downstream effects of KMT2D and KDM6A mutations on gene expression and cellular function. These targets may lead to the development of new treatments aimed at improving cognitive function and other symptoms.

recentBreakthroughs.title: Improved diagnostic criteria for Kabuki syndrome
recentBreakthroughs.description: Refined diagnostic criteria for Kabuki syndrome have been proposed, incorporating genetic and clinical data to improve diagnostic accuracy and facilitate earlier diagnosis. This includes a scoring system based on key clinical features and genetic testing results.
